Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Method and Tool for Time-Domain Processing of Densely Sampled Signals
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader/commercial potential of this I-Corps project will be primarily in the semiconductor manufacturing industry. This industry desperately needs a tool for extraction of useful information from a large number of densely sampled sensor readings. This need is especially emphasized by the recent dramatic increases both in the number of available sensor readings, as well as the sampling rates at which those readings are collected. This tool is expected to serve a dual purpose in this industry; providing access to information to enable decision making and serve as a data reduction tool which reduces information loss. Furthermore, such a tool is expected to be useful in any industry that employs non-rotating equipment, including the oil and gas extraction, refineries, chemical process industry etc. It is expected that the volume of data gathered in many such industries will continue to increase, further motivating the need to develop and invest in such feature extraction and data reduction tools.

This I-Corps project will focus on exploring and improving potentials of a technological innovation that will enable a fully automated extraction of informative features from signals generated by non-rotating equipment and processes. Such a tool will be able to reduce the original data into a feature set that is significantly smaller in size than the original signal, thus enabling a significantly easier data management and data mining in a large number of densely sampled sensor signals. The method in the foundation of this tool has recently been developed. It starts by segmenting the signal into a series of steady-state and transient portions, after which each segment of the data is used to construct a number of statistics-based and dynamics based signatures. The ultimate goal is to create a tool that will achieve all this with minimal or, hopefully no human involvement, in contrast to the currently used approaches, which require extensive manual inputs and analyses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Semiconductor manufacturing involves a large number of complex processes being executed sequentially on a workpiece, to create components critical to the functioning of electronic devices. The evolutions in the quality and functionality of these devices has been driven by rapid improvements in semiconductor technology, with ever smaller component dimensions being demanded. This technology progression has been enabled by tight control and consistent execution of manufacturing processes. As the dimensions and tolerances on semiconductor components become restrictively small, the ability to reliably, and hence profitably, manufacture them is a growing challenge. This requires that manufacturing equipment must function in near perfect condition, behavioral changes must be recognized and localized rapidly, variations in product quality must be caught as they are generated and advanced process control must be realized. Where expert knowledge and human intervention for decision making were previously sufficient, the need to handle phenomena that cannot be observed by simple human intervention, due to the data volume and scale as well as the need to handle high dimensional data, has become an urgent need of this industry.

Naturally, there have also been developments in manufacturing equipment employed in this industry. While the equipment has long been equipped with a large array of sensors, generally in excess of 100, these sensors have traditionally collected data at relatively low sampling rates, below 1 Hz. A recognition of the need for data-driven decisions and control has seen denser data in recent years, now commonly between 3-10 Hz. The signals collected at these rates capture even short-lived effects with higher fidelity. In order to drive improved performance in this industry, as well as many others, it is necessary to extract actionable information from the raw data, i.e. extract useful information that can provide insights which in turn enable appropriate actions. Unfortunately, tools for information extraction have not evolved at the same rates as the sensors, equipment and process complexity.

The solution proposed by our group at the University of Texas at Austin enables extraction of information from equipment data by utilizing an approach for automatic segmentation of signals into steady state and transient portions (Figure 1) before summarizing each of these segments into a set of features (Figure 2). The steady state segments are represented by traditional characteristics such as mean, standard deviation, peak-to-peak values and maximum or minimum values. On the other hand, the transient phenomena are summarized using a set of characteristics that capture the underlying system dynamics. These characteristics include, for instance, the settling time, rise time, overshoot and undershoot. This then represents what shall be referred to as a “dynamics-inspired” feature set, as it captures the underlying dynamics of the system and process. The tool developed is able to perform this entire process in an automated manner, allowing implementation on a fab-wide scale. The resulting information has already been shown to enable improvements in a number of critical decision making tasks associated with semiconductor manufacturing.

The I-Corps experience enabled us to determine some critical elements that would be required to successfully transition the developed methodology into a viable solution for industry to adopt. The interactions with persons from various industry made us aware of very similar challenges of access to useful information, buried in large amounts of data that cannot be manually interpreted or analyzed, across various functions within these industries. Further, we learnt that the likelihood of adoption and utilization of such solutions is greatly improved by the availability of a graphical user interface, which had not been part of the scope of our work prior to our I-Corps project. This also lead us into exploration of the possibility of merging this solution with solutions that use information garnered from the raw data to enable automated or computer aided decision making in such environments. The suppliers of such tools find their solutions’ performances are confined and determined by the quality of the data and the information extracted from it.

While the technology readiness level of the developed technology is quite high, it has become evident that some further work remains before productization is possible. The optimal channel to make this tool available to the semiconductor industry also remains an open issue. Finally, the modifications required for other industries to benefit from this work must also be studied.
